entry.title: Supra holders, move active stashes to a DEX
entry.summary: Why I've been moving active stash to DEXes
entry.content:
• Intro
  • Current Supra-listing CEXes
    • Governance
    • Market M-ing
    • Spot
    • Perpetual Futures aka Perps
  • DEXes
    • DEX benefits to you and Supra ecosystem
    • Slippage and fees
    • Dexlyn
    • Atmos
    • Solido
    • What else is coming
  • Take-aways and call to action

Intro​

Some people who advocate DEXes are decentralization fanatics, others are conspiracy theorists, and some "all of the above".

There are also pragmatists in this group. In this post I share my pragmatic arguments in favor of moving your active stash to a DEX.

Note that this is specific to Supra and my own purpose, which is to see the project grow and, with it, the value it provides to its ecosystem. More value means more growth and a higher coin price. I view Supra as my "enterprise" blockchain holding: I'd like it to see grow as a normal for-profit business would.

note

I elaborate because I also hold xx coin which is more of a "cause coin" for me and where I'm not pragmatic in terms of the token price, earnings and such.

In the case of xx coin, I'm interested in "economically-sustainable private messaging" and have very different concerns.

In the case of Supra, I don't think centralization is bad. I simply don't like how these particular unregulated guys run their business.

Another special circumstance is Supra is a good L1 platform for DEX markets, so I also have - all Supra holders and stakers should have - a conflict of interest in their mind.

Current Supra-listing CEXes​

I don't expect to add anything new here, as cryptocurrency DEXes have been around for a decade or more, and pragmatic arguments against CEXes have been around longer.

Briefly, from the viewpoint explained above (meaning: pragmatic, Supra-specific arguments from an enterprise POV)...

  • Lack of transparency: this is really the worst part
  • Poor business practices: we don't know who and how (why, because no transparency) not only in terms of transparency, but also in terms of governance
  • Leverage (Futures): this isn't bad in itself, but I think it's a major tool used in market manipulation

Regarding the lack of transparency, folks on X like to make fun of crypto/DeFi fans saying the folks who claimed zero regulation was good, start whining when their altcoin gets smashed on the same markets. I agree with them:

  • I may decide to participate in a zero-regulation market (a DEX, for example) and I won't whine if lose
  • Zero-regulation (or "extremely lax" regulation) CEX could work if these exchanges voluntarily shared data that should be shared. But they don't share anything of substance, while regulated CEXes probably collect and share too much, which increases costs for no benefit to users. There's nothing "in-between" which is a shame
info

CEXes also have some good sides and advantages. For example, most of these are still true:

  • Low latency, very suitable for frequent trading (exchange)
  • Better features for advanced traders (such as leverage, automation, APIs, clients)
  • Convenience

CEXes still command close to 80% of crypto spot trading and there's nothing wrong with using them. People say "not your private keys not your coins", but I would guess more people lost their coins in self-custody than at CEXes.

Governance​

Transparency is sometimes legally mandated, but for unregulated exchanges it's merely a choice.

There's nothing that prevents them from busting manipulators, reporting money launderes, and such. From what I can tell the unregulated CEXes where Supra is listed are doing the bare minimum.

Another area of governance is operations. If you work for a regulated FSI player you're simply not allowed to do certain things the weird or wrong way. There are checks and checks of checks.

For example, using plain text passwords could be grounds for dismissal, and you'll get discovered because Ops don't run Security. But the ByBit guy transferred $1.5B to the North Korean hackers because ByBit used a DIY workflow "invented" by ByBit. Had they followed practices in place in the UK or US, it'd be slower, safer and more expensive. They probably didn't like the speed and cost and thought they were smarter than hackers...

This argument applies to DEXes as well (were bugs may go undetected due to corner cutting in development, operations or auditing), but it's not an argument against regulated CEXes. Unfortunately no Western CEX list Supra at this time, so there's no "better" CEX to go to.

Market M-ing​

One example of poor transparency is market making (or manipulating... ). You can't even know which it is.

Consider this screenshot of trades in SUPRA/USDT (Spot) taken yesterday.

This is not normal. A market maker would create buy and sell orders and let others take them.

But we see here both buys and sells are happening, and only of these particular orders:

  • Are there no other buyers/sellers whose order would be in this list
  • Why would anyone buy and sell within seconds like that?

This looks like market manipulation more than market making.

At times, the MM guys go on a day trip or take a day off, and then you see the extent of it:

I checked the smaller pair on this exchange, SUPRA/USDC, and it's even worse there.

Again, the problem here isn't that there's a market "maker". The problem is that they're "trade marker".

If you make market, you create buy/sell orders that others "take"" (with matching sell/buy orders). If there's no genuine activity, market maker's orders just sit there.

Seeing a lot more volume when they're not day-tripping means when they're gone there's no trading. Obviously, this means bots are rampant, the MM guys engage in wash trading.

And, related to transparency, you don't even know who's MM-ing, who's paying them, and if they're actively trading against exchange's retail users. But, you can probably assume the worst.

info

Binance recently busted a crooked MM and confiscated their funds.

I've never heard of anything like tha thappening at any of the exchanges that list Supra and I assume "reasonably crooked" MMers operate even on well-run unregulated exchanges.

Spot​

This was taken today.

In numeric order:

  • Trust score (a DIY matric by Coin Gecko) is missing and who knows if the stats reported by the exchange can be trusted. Business as usual...
  • Ridiculously high volume. What's going on? Good luck finding out. The exchange is not obliged to share this info or provide aggregate figures of top traders.
  • Another pair from the same exchange has 1% of total volume on one day, 20% on another. No one asks any questions, because no one is supposed to answer them.

Clearly there's a lot of "campaign" trading which would normally pique the interest of regulators or even the exchanges themselves to see if some customers are attempting to manipulate prices and hurt retail users.

Perpetual Futures aka Perps​

Perpetual futures are basically entries in a database which is a closed zero-sum system where there is no Supra involved at all.

In fact, there's no USD involved either! Yes, it says SUPRA/USDT, but understand that the market doesn't need either.

  • A DB is created, and named after a pair such as SUPRA/USDT
  • To play, gamers deposit USDT "at the entrance" in order to be able to enter and play, but just like Supra (the other side of this pair), the Perps DB does not "use" USDT. It's just a database
  • Next, players play against each other, and the survivors "unlock" thei USDT deposit and collect deposit of other users who've lost, while the CEX retains trading revenues
  • Players could deposit collateral in gemstones, Litecoin or something else. USDT is simply what's most convenient in this case because it maps 1:1 to a side in this pair
  • Players cannot take Supra out of this market, because there's no Supra, as we've said earlier

Next, realize that Perps provide leverage

There are two interesting things about this.

The first is, players can deposit 10 USDT "at the entrance" and play with 500 USDT. This speeds up the CEX'es "time to fleecing". Notice how it also makes $500 available to CEX interest-free. It's a closed system so as long as they liquidate overleveraged positions in time, there's no chance for the CEX to lose here. This is obviously much better (for CEXes) and worse for customers. Instead of hesitating to send users to Futures section, they employ "dark UI patterns" to attract users to Perps. MEXC won't even show Spot in top menu once you enter Futures!

Point 2: with a 50x leverage you can buy, but also sell, 50x more Supra than you could normally sell. That means Perps are the place to go to smash a project or simply cause price-impacting swings in Spot SUPRA/USDT as "the tail is wagging the dog".

But it's even worse than that! We said "50x more Supra than you could normally sell", but in order to sell you'd have to buy. With Perps not only do you can sell 50x more, but you don't have to buy any at all. You deposit USDT at the entrance, lever up 40x, smack Supra, and exit with more USDT in your pockets.

You may wonder why this doesn't equally work for buyers. The truth is it does, but that doesn't make this setup better. If marketplace owner determines you're trading in a way meant to manipulate Spot prices - for example you're shorting in Perps with 40x and and have buy orders in Spot - they should step in and do something about that. These cowboy CEXes do not.

I think unregulated cowboy exchanges don't do anything about it. If anything, they encourage it.

This is from SUPRA/USDT Perps yesterday and I think it shows a problem. In (2), Perps volume is rapidly incrasing on no big changes in price before 14:26. Why would that happen?

This below is Spot. Selling at scale starts at 14:26.

Perps dump first, Spot follows. Seven percent drop (or over 200% profit, if you're leveraged 40x), on no news - the price even (almost) reocvered hours later.

Am I "sure" this is manipulation? Of course I'm not. As we've said, they don't have to tell us anything.

"If you don't want to play in our casino, go elsewhere" is the message. Fair enough! Maybe I'll take my ball and go elsewhere!

We've seen enough to know that they're often up to no good.

Even without any forensic evidence related to Market M-ing and such, evidence of dark UI patterns exist and is plentiful.

For example, you can see Futures from Spot, but you can't see Spot markets from Futures page.

Enter Futures... It's one way street - no link back to Spot!

As soon as you switch, "Las Vegas experience" kicks in - there are constant promotions for reckless behavior (high leverage, commission free trading), there are casino-like pop-ups, etc.

DEXes​

I've used the early ones on bitcoin network and it was bad! I remember how we'd see a sell order, submit our matching buy order and then wait, and wait, awnd wait - usually for more than 1 hour - before we could see our order on chain (6 confirmations, remember?). Anyone who saw your order in mempool could front-run you if they wanted to pay a slightly higher transaction fee.

Things are better now. This aren't "latest and greatest", but they're recent enough (2025). The first is DEX share in Spot volumes.

Perps are harder, as mentioned earlier, but both blockchains and DEX tech are getting better.

CEXes have noticed. See this, for example:

We need to rethink our listing process at @coinbase

There are several reasons, but in January commissions from memecoin trading were huge and CEXes just couldn't keep up - all the action was happening on Solana, basically.

But it's not just memecoins, it's also "traditional" coins which probably don't last long enough and CEXes don't want to miss out.

DEXes don't solve all the problems with unregulated CEXes mentioned above, and some maybe aren't even solvable.

For example, leveraged perpetual futures are also available on on-chain DEXes. But at least you don't lend your own funds to a CEX interest-free to use them against you.

DEX benefits to you and Supra ecosystem​

I'll keep this simple because it ought to be obvious and it was explained at the top:

  • Better transparency, fairness and more disclosure than unregulated CEXes
  • Convenience, performance and features are very close - it's good enough for non-professionals
  • Supra-based DEXes trade on-chain, chain earns revenue, more people buy Supra to pay for those fees
  • Supra-based DEXes need liquidity. You can stake DEX pools and make money doing that

It's also a way to distribute risk for your "active" Supra stash - part of your tokens that moves more often, as opposed to staked Supra that is likely quite static. You may do something like this:

  • 1/3 of active stash on a regulated CEX if you feel the need to day trade from time to time (some people prefer unregulatd; I do too, but not any of the current ones)
  • 1/3 in Staking or LP Staking on Supra-based DEX number 1 (e.g. Dexlyn)
  • 1/3 on Staking or LP Staking on Supra-based DEX number 2 (e.g. Atmos)

Slippage and fees​

Everyone knows Supra is fast and transaction costs are very low, Supra's DORA (Distributed Oracles) provides up to date price feeds quickly, but one "sensitive" bit about DEXes is slippage and fees.

There isn't enough independent detailed information available to compare, but anecodtally:

  • An unregulated CEX may have a 0.5% "taker" fee
  • Dexlyn may have a 0.3% commission, and there's "slippage" that's to be kept at below 0.5% (default)

The problem is we don't really know how it behaves (slippage). From my experience with smaller (below $1,000) amounts, Dexlyn worked fine when I compared the price from that UI with CEX prices in another browser.

info

Maybe this doesn't work that great with larger orders, but I haven't seen any evidence, so I can't conclude much from unsubstantiated "concern trolling".

Yes, maybe, if you Swap $10,000today you'd be hit with 2% slippage. I don't know, but it's possible.. But don't do $10K at a time if you notice at $2K it's already higher than 0.5%!

For normal retail use swapping on Dexlyn right now will cost you up to 0.8% (up to 0.5% slippage plus fixed 0.3% commission). It can be below 0.5% - less than you pay at a low-cost deregulated CEX!

This may change for better or worse, but it's quite simple and low-risk: don't use a crap DEX you've never heard of and run small tests before ramping up like a degen! Transactions take seconds, so I'm sure you can spend 30 seconds trying with $10, $50, and $100 before you try with $500. They also have a Testnet to try with fake coins first.

Supra Network makes it possible to address most of those problems, so while slippage has historically been a week spot for DEXes, it's not supposed to happen on Supra if DEXes make good use of those L1 features.

Now let's see about some of the current DEXes.

Dexlyn​

This one's been in poduction since February. No bad news so far.

Two audits. Swapping and bridging work well for me:

  • I usually Swap Supra into dexUSDC
  • Another thing I do is I send ERC-20 USDC tokens to Dexlyn from Ethereum newtork, to fund my dexUSDC address

Current disadvantages:

  • Swap only (same as CEX "Market Order")
  • Only SUPRA/dexUSDC (and dexUSDC is Dexlyn-wrapped ERC20 USDC)

They started just last month so obviously these are temporary. They recently said they're going to add more currency pairs and Perps, so I think major updates are coming.

While I've said Perps are bad (and that's true) the fact is there's demand and they'll have to be LP-stakeds, so it's less bad than on deregulated CEXes. Secondly, some of the LP stake will be in Supra as well, unlike on CEXes where the entire Perps system is funded with (essentialy) fake US dollars.

info

Dexlyn uses own bridge, and has passed two audits.

They also have multiple dApps, so do your own research, to see what was audited, by whom, and how.

Swap dApp: https://app.dexlyn.com/

Atmos​

Currently in Testnet, getting close to Mainnet.

I haven't used it on Mainnet yet, but Atmos Testnet looks very nice.

Unique features on their roadmap:

  • Down-Cost Averaging (DCA) may be delivered before Dexlyn's since it's already in the UI
  • Limit orders - also something that Dexyn does not have, as "Swap" is like "Market" order on CEX
  • More pairs - their Testnet currently features USDC, ETH, BTC, but I haven't looked at how they do it

Their documentation has more details on their roadmap, but I highlight the three distinguishing ones.

info

I believe Atmos won't use Dexlyn's Ethereum bridge, so it may be "logically segregated" risk-wise (although L1 itself is "shared").

Atmos dApp: https://app.atmosprotocol.com/

Solido​

Solido is different. Currently also Testnet-only.

Their stablecoin (which Atmos on Testnet already has in its pools) is an over-collateralized synthetic USD stablecoin.

So yes, it's a "fake USD" - like USDT, but with crypto collateral. And Supra's DORA is used for price feeds, obviously, to figure out what's the right exchange rates (and sufficient levels of collateral) ought to be.

The UI is a bit confusing, but I like it.

note

This may seem like a lot more risk than USDT, but is it really?

It's collateralized, so unlike USDT which is backed by the non-independently audited Tether, CIRCLE token is backed by other cryptocurrency tokens/assets.

You can borrow CIRCLE with Supra (or other) and you can do stuff with CIRCLE in Atmos or elsewhere.

You can also stake to earn yield there.

I have not checked any security- or design-related docs.

Solido (testnet) dApp: https://testnet.solido.money/

What else is coming​

Check each of these projects' roadmaps, but also check Supra DeFi Revolution for more on what's coming to Supra and what these three projects will build upon.

Take-aways and call to action​

The current lot of unregulated exchanges that list Supra today are in my opinion not good hombres, folks.

We have a solution: several in fact. Dexlyn today and two more are coming on weeks.

Move at least 50% of your active stash to DEXes, and split the risk among them (for example, 50% of DEX LP funds on Dexlyn, 40% on Atmos, 10% in Solido). When you need coins to trade, unstake them. When they're not being traded, they earn yield.

info

I mentioned Dexlyn and Atmos may use different DEX and bridge tech and you can also split those among two wallets to have the DEX part of "active stash" segreagated on both dApp and wallet level.

DEX and CEX have different risk profile, so holding 50% of the active stash at a good regulated CEX isn't more or less risky, IMO - it's just risky in different ways.

That arrangement benefits the Supra ecosystem much more than providing CEXes with free liquidity which is mostly used to damage both holders and the token.

It's good for your staking, it's good for your LPing, it's good for the price, and so on.

There are virtually no downsides unless you day trade. For many it can be cheaper. I didn't even realize that until I started writing this post.

info

Assume there's a LP where you can earn 5% APR and you have 10,000 SUPRA, half of which is staked. That earns you 5,000 x 5% per year (250 SUPRA).

Now assume you buy and sell the other half, 5,000 SUPRA, weekly - maybe you pick what you'll think will go up (Supra or dexUSDC) and buy one of them.

You make 4 trades a month and pay 0.75%. 20,000 x 0.0075 = 150 SUPRA in fees. This would still be 100 SUPRA in fees on a low cost unregulated CEX, by the way!

We don't even assume that you can stake the other half of your stash from Monday to Friday (if you trade every Sunday, which means you can un-stake on Friday) and ignoire the fact that you'd pay fees on a CEX, too!

250 in staking earnings minus 150 in DEX fees and slippage = 100 SUPRA. You're ahead by 100 (at least, before considering CEX fees) which is 1% APR from NOT using a CEX!

It is true that some CEXes let you stake coins parked there, but none support Supra staking and and even when they do you can make more by staking on your own which in StarKey is easy.

Remember that this approach not only benefits your "active stash", but it also benefits the Supra Network, Supra dApp creators including DEXes, and many others.

It's a good idea to have some Supra at a CEX. It's a different risk profile, it's convenient, you don't need 20 different wallets, etc.

I won't recommend any particular CEX, but my own plan is to move to a regulated CEX. I didn't expect I'd every want to do that, but now I do. After watching the current unregulated exchanges since Supra's launch (four months now), I don't like what I see. Unregualted CEXes could do a better job without anyone forcing them, but they prefer not to.

entry.title: SupraNS (SNS) names with hexadecimal symbols
entry.summary: SupraNS names available for purchase
entry.content:
Today I registered some hex names.

They're not just "fancy" but have use cases, one of which I just added to SupraNS. Such names are not novel, but they're rarely used and, in my opinion, interesting. So I'll write a few words about that.

Say you get a SNs name that consists of hexadecimal symbols ([0-9][A-F]). Example: b00b5.

Is that interesting and/or useful? Let's take a closer look.

Downsides of hex SNS names​

A "hex name" can be dangerous if you get autocorrected when entering such SNS names. For example, a payee may end up entering boobs.supra in StarKey wallet and send funds to the wrong address.

But that risk depends on the name and whether the "wrong" SNS exists (in many cases it would). Most names shouldn't get autocorrected (especially not b00b5). In some cases hex names will be less autocorrect-prone because they may not match common misspellings (thanks to the fact that they usually contain digits).

Another danger is visual confusion, where someone misreads 1abe1.supra and sends funds to label.supra. One workaround is to register the both SNS names. Another is to not make such mistakes (e.g. use a good font, or advise your counterparty to use copy-and-paste rather than view-and-retype when entering your SNS hex address).

Benefits of hex SNS names​

First, they're fancy and can be c001 (somebody snapped this one before me).

Second, they cay be practical. If you create a wallet address that matches your SupraNS name for easy address recognition (e.g. in SupraScan.io or API output), it's easier to use or develop. For example, I may have SNS b00b5.supra mapped to wallet address b00b57fef64e98e838eef231215dd0e7fa634d2fd70e75ae50df3a2959eba2f4.

Or, the proverbial Alice may be boob5 + a, which allows me up to 26 test addresses for easy testing:

alice.b00b5.supra # b00b5a7fef64e98e838eef231215dd0e7fa634d2fd70e75ae50df3a2959eba2f
jane.b00b5.supra  # b00b5j16c6bde199856efd1204ae840d21e3a26d0c501fb1521a0d9f7302934d
note

Note that StarKey won't create vanity addresses for you. Even if it could, it'd be slow for anything but 3 letters.

You'd have to generate such addresses outside and import their private key to StarKey. You don't need that for SupraScan.io, CLI or API use cases.

Other notes​

SNS names can be as short as 3 single-byte characters.

Long hex names are impractical: hard to read, hard to tyype. If you combine two "hex words" (say, b19b00b5), that's probably the upper limit. Three words are usually hard to read. And - isn't a hexadecimal symbol, so b19-b00b5 is possible in SNS but can't be mapped to a wallet address.

The last bit is related to those who want to use vanity addresses. Today it's still quite hard to generate them for 7 or more characters.

Therefore I recommend SNS length of hex names to be in the range 3-6 (characters). If you don't plan to use vanity addresses, then up to 10(-ish) may be fine, assuming you don't pick a lame name.

Where to buy or register hex names​

I registered a bunch of hex names according to the above considerations: most are 3-6 characters and therefore suitable for pairing with vanity addresses. Some are longer, but I registered only those long hex names that I really liked.

You can find them by sorting the table of available names by Comment and looking for comments that contain "hex".

Some good ones (including 3 letter names) are still available through Dexlyn's SupraNS dApp.

Update (March 25, 2025)​

SupraNS names are now transferable directly from Dexlyn's dApp UI.

There's no marketplace yet, but we have been gifting and exchanging names in a trusted way.

entry.title: Buy my SupraNS names
entry.summary: SupraNS names available for purchase
entry.content:
I've registered a few SupraNS names to keep them until those who want them decide to buy them... or not.

info

SupraNS is the officicial name system of the Supra network.

Its function is similar to what ENS does on the Ethereum network: initially it will be used for wallet address aliasing.

You can find more about it at the link below and in the official documentation (linked from the site below).

Currently Supra has just one wallet, StarKey, and StarKey is about to add SupraNS support for addresses in coming days or weeks.

At that time SupraNS names will become useful. Currently they have just one use: speculation, which is what I've been doing.

Another important feature that's still missing is the ability to transfer SupraNS registration ownership.

Because of that there are no marketplaces for SupraNS trading either, but that's precisely why I listed mine on a Web site: I've no idea when that may become available which is why I'm posting those SupraNS names on a Web site.

See the list of my SupraNS names at https://SupraNS.name. Screenshot:

By now you may beginning to wonder how can one sell a SupraNS name when transfer isn't possible. I plan to use escrow service provided by someone in the Supra community, and will commit to transferring the name if the agreed-upon payment is promptly made to the person who helps with escrow.

Transfers can't happen before the API becomes available, but prices may be agreed upon and funds transferred before SupraNS becomes popular and before Internet auctions become available.

info

The site has the prices, too, but those are not fixed (as explained on the site).

I'll probably use them as initial prices in auctions on a SupraNS marketplace.

To be honest, I don't think the prices of SupraNS names will be anywhere close to Solana's (let alone Ethereum's), but that's not relevant.

Initially SupraNS registrations were very cheap. After the first 10,000 registrations were reached the doubled the prices and they'll hike them again after 15,000 registrations which should happen within days of StarKey adding support for SupraNS. Now most StarKey users have no idea about SupraNS.

I would definiively recommend SupraNS to StarKey users and to anyone who runs a business on Supra because it's a useful feature. It's been useful on all chains and it will be on this one as well. But speculating in hem may be risky.

For that same reason I'm not going to hype these or claim that these "may" become a source of huge profits (10-baggers!). I don't think that will happen. Buy 'em if you need 'em.

note

I actually have more than those that I've listed at SupraNS.name, but for various reasons I'm not rushing to sell them.

More on that and other SupraNS topics in a future blog post when SupraNS becomes trade-able.

Introduction​

Because of gross incompetence in XX Community (not all of them, but more than enough to paralyze any corrective action in the DAO), the network is suffering from pool infestation.

I recently started "validating with a twist" (more about that here and earlier posts), and block validator pools using my own pool.

Two new nodes added​

Today I've got two more nodes online, so now I have five.

This is already one node too many - considering that cMix (mixnet) group size is five - but that is the very problem the XX Network community won't do anything about.

I tried to talk some sense into them, but they won't listen so now I'm just one of several centralized pools who run more nodes than it takes to form a random mixnet group.

entry.title: How to add WXX (ERC-20) xx coin to Supra StarKey
entry.summary: How to add WXX to Supra StarKey and get access to Supra DEX services
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • Non-native tokens/coins/NFTs in StarKey
  • WXX contract
  • Get StarKey
  • Add WXX to StarKey
  • Why do all this?
    • Supra DEXes
    • xx coin and Supra ecosystem
      • SupraNS
  • How to buy Supra
  • HOw to buy WXX
  • Next steps

Introduction​

StarKey wallet is the native wallet for Supra L1.

xx coin is the native token of xx Network, a L1 network with integrated mixnet services for post-quantum privacy.

WXX is an XX Foundation-issued, Ethereum-wrapped ERC20 token. It is also used on Uniswap DEX.

This post explores StarKey for xx coin users (and speculators).

Non-native tokens/coins/NFTs in StarKey​

Supra StarKey is expanding its token support and currently support for 20 or so is natively built-in. What about the smalle ones, such as xx coin?

According to StarKey FAQs:

As of now, StarKey supports a variety of tokens, including all ERC-20 tokens, as well as tokens on the Aptos, Sui, and Solana blockchains

This looks promising. Let's try!

WXX contract​

Go to contract address and copy contract (Token Contract (WITH 9 Decimals) on right-hand side).

I got it from https://etherscan.io/token/0x171120219d3223E008558654ec3254A0F206edb2, but I suggest you get it from Uniswap by yourself.

Get StarKey​

Download StarKey by following links from the official site (www.supra.com) or the StarKey app page.

Currently desktop versions have more features, but I can't think of any that would interfere with WXX.

I used StarKey on Chromium.

Add WXX to StarKey​

warning

Make a backup of your StarKey pass phrase. Like with other non-custodial walles, there's no other way to get access.

The pencil icon is where you toggle display (ON/OFF) of existing tokens. But WXX does not exist, so we need to add it.

Once in Manage Token page, you can toggle other tokens (Solana, etc.), but to add WXX you need to click on the + icon to add a custom token.

This is where the WXX contract is needed:

  • Network: Ethereum
  • Contract: paste the WXX contract address you got earlier

The rest will be auto-populated.

You have added WXX!

Now you can go back to Manage Tokens (the pencil icon). Use the magnifying glass icon to find WXX and click the star to make the token a favorite.

Finally, we can click on WXX to receive or send (ETH is required for transaction fees) WXX.

tip

I encountered a problem with StarKey v2.1.2 in this last step: no coins - built-in or manually added - with zero balance would be displayed.

A workaround I discovered:

  • Click on All Networks at the top
  • Click on Testnet and then again on Mainnets and return to wallet

That makes all zero-balance coins appear in view. They may disappear again, but at least you can copy an addresses to fund it and make it a non-zero balance address, or repeat the workaround to view them again at any time.

Why do all this?​

The display problem is temporary and maybe you won't even notice it.

Why bother in the first place? Several reasons.

Supra DEXes​

WXX in your StarKey will (eventually) be trade-able on Supra DEXes.

Currently, one is online (Dexlyn) and more are coming (Atmos, for example).

But again - why bother?

  • Low cost: Dexlyn's DEX charges 0.3% and transaction fees are negligible
  • Fast: transactions take seconds
  • The first native stablecoin on Supra is Dexlyn's dexUSDC, which is USDC (ERC-20) wrapped on Supra L1 using Dexlyn's Ethereum bridge, so you will be able to
    • Trade xx coin for dexUSDC
    • Exit/enter with WXX and USDC (ERC-20)
info

Dexlyn DEX does not yet support a variety of coins - it just launched last week.

The above will be possible when generic ERC-20 coins/tokens become supported on Dexlyn DEX. You would then add your own pairs (such as dexWXX/dexUSDC).

Alternatively - see below - wait for Supra's own cross-chain support.

As an example of low fees, here's an example of a transaction involving Dexlyn's Ethereum bridge.

On Supra L1 side, the fee was US$0.000. Affordable, right?

As you can see the exact amount is 0.001001 SUPRA ($0.00001742). Transaction fees will go up as L1 gets more busy, but even if they go up 10 times, it'll still be cheap! Did I mention that transactions complete in low single digit seconds?

What else should you know?

Your StarKey WXX can be sent to any wallet that supports it, and private key of the address can be exported if you want to simply import the address to another wallet.

For Dexlyn's DEX, they have instructions how to fund dexUSDC by sending USDC (ERC-20) to their bridge.

The only thing missing is dexWXX-dexUSDC pair and the correspoinding Liquidity Pool.

info

If you want to stay up-to-date, follow Dexlyn and Aptos on X.

  • Dexlyn: https://dexlyn.com/
  • Aptos: https://aptos.dev/

Next key step for Delxyn - in the context of this post - is to add support for arbitrary DIY pairs and pools. To trade WXX on Dexlyn DEX we'd need to wrap it, and trade dexWXX/dexUSDC.

For Aptos, it's to launch.

Later on when arbitrary pairs become available, we should be able to wrap WXX on Supra into something like dexWXX and trade/swap/send/receive natively on Supra L1.

info

In a week or so EVM will be available on Supra testnet.

Technically savvy folks could take the WXX contract (published by the XX Foundation) and release $SXX (Supra-wrapped XX on Supra L1) on Supra testnet.

xx coin and Supra ecosystem​

Supra is just getting started. It's 10 weeks old.

What's coming soon is:

  • Native EVM support (the flagship language is Move, and MoveVM is the first VM supported since TGE), which means the Ethereum Smart Contract used to issue WXX could be issued on Supra L1 without using Ethereum L1
  • Bridgeless (yes, bridgeless) cross-chain swapping on Supra. When a Substate chain (probably Polkadot or Kusama) becomes supported, xx Network could be supported as well, but xx Network would have to update chain to support latest and greatest Substrate SDK features

Either of these would be a huge improvement over WXX.

In the first case, with an SdexXX (assuming this be the name of a xx ERC-20 token created on Supra L1 using the same contract that was used for WXX) it would take seconds to exit to native xx tokens. And it'd cost almost nothing. Sound good?

In the second case, WXX would become redundant and xx Network wouldn't even need a bridge.

SupraNS​

Another interesting thing is SupraNS, the official Supra name system, i.e. "Supra's ENS". It's here and requires Supra tokens to register. It's much cheaper than ENS, which is great, but because it just launched there's no wallet that supports it.

info

StarKey will likely be the first to support SupraNS.

With SupraNS support in StarKey it will be easier to send tokens to Supra wallet.

Later on, when SupraNS allows for more entries (such as URLs and maybe arbitrary fields), we may be able to add things like nicknames from xx Network Haven (the reference quantum-resistant messaging app).

How to buy Supra​

note

This is not a recommendation or advice.

If you don't want to use Dexlyn and only want to try WXX in StarKey, you don't even need Supra. You just need WXX and $ETH for transaction fees. This will use Ethereum L1 so it won't be particularly interesting, exciting, fast, or cheap.

If you want to play with Supra tokens, SupraNS or Dexlyn DEX, today you need just 2 dollars.

Registering a SupraNS name now takes 1-40 SUPRA (depending on name length) and transaction fees are low as shown above.

If you want to play with this stuff (e.g. SupraNS), you need to fund your StarKey with either $USDC (ERC-20; add it through Manage Tokens). You can use $USDC to swap to dexUSDC and/or $SUPRA. Or you can use just $SUPRA.

  • $USDC to $SUPRA - Dexlyn has instructions on how to fund $dexUSDC with $USDC over their Ethereum bridge. This is possible, but slightly complicated. I'd just buy $SUPRA and send it to my StarKey.
  • Supra tokens get be swapped for dexUSDC on Dexlyn DEX at https://app.dexlyn.com/
  • Native $SUPRA - buy it on MEXC (most xx users have an account there) and withdraw it to your StarKey
    • You can also get $SUPRA from Houdini, SimpleSwap, and few other CEX (see CoinMarketCap or CoinGecko)
note

If you want to try out existing dexUSDC-Supra Liquidity Pool, you need to stake it with more than $2, so I don't recommend this.

That's no longer playing, but speculating/investing or whatever you want to call it.

Once you have $SUPRA you can register SupraNS names and buy/sell $dexUSDC. You can also pay for Supra L1 transaction fees.

HOw to buy WXX​

Get them on Uniswap or SimpleSwap.

Next steps​

That's not all! Supra has quite a few other tricks up their sleeve! Follow SupraLabs on X to see what they're up to.

If you're a Supra user interested in privacy, you can follow xx Network to learn how StarKey and dApps could use xx Networks' mixnet (cmix) to provide privacy for its users./

info

xx Network's Proxxy can be modified to support Supra L1 and route all client RPC calls through its mixnet, adding seconds of latency, but increasing privacy of the user.

Good use cases for StarKey and Proxxy: regular wallet transactions and anything else that can tolerate an extra 2-3 seconds required to route (encrypted) Supra RPC client calls through xx Network's cMix mixnet.

Introduction​

As described here, my pool-blocking pool is up and running!

This post provides some updates for community members and my nominators.

High-level Overview​

Commissions​

My goal is to cover my hosting expenses and get some minimal rewards for the work I do for the community (meaning, not just "OS maintenance", but development, testing and implementing these blocking approaches).

As the two nodes are new, I had no idea how they may perform.

I started with 5%, but cut it a bit to keep it roughly acceptable to nominators.

Each node currently makes less than 10 xx per (0.05) per day.

It doesn't cover my hosting, but I'll think about that at a later time once pool blocking is in full swing.

Blocking​

I've been developing and testing aproaches for blocking, reporting, etc.

This afternoon I started blocking "in production". The first target is MONEYTEAM: they run more than 5 nodes, and do it in different regions. An enemy of the network.

First, I find their cMix IDs in the wallet.

Then I use the workflow from my Github repository (see Appendix A) to find their IP addresses, add them to a list and then run the script that denies them access. The script - as posted on Github - works fine with generic ufw settings recommended in the xx Network Handbook, so you may use it by yourself if you want.

Monitoring and reporting​

This is time consuming. I've been planning, evaluating and developing an approach to gather data and produce reports.

This is important for several reasons, for example:

  • Nominators who potentially compromise a few percent in yield may want to know if I'm really blocking as I say I do.
  • I need to know if I"m realy blocking (as I can't claim I am if I'm not) and how well.
  • I need the data to see how effective my approach is, and to estimate losses caused to the pools.

So far I got monitoring working in a prototype. That means it's not "automated", but the steps work.

Today I deployed the rules to ARMAIRANCAP-ALFA targeting MONEYTEAM as I've mentioned earlier.

I have a report generator that lists cMix rounds failed due to timeouts in last 24 hours.

That's actually from yesterday - an accidental timeout (before I started blocking) - but I can't tell which round failed to my blocking and which to other reasons.

My report looks for specific (pool cMix IDs stored in a DB), so this doesn't list rounds that failed with random nodes.

This is just over a 7 hour period and from only one of my nodes!

I hope this is as motivating to my nominators as it is to me!

Analysis​

Based on this small sample, let us assume 170 points gets taken away from them every eight hours. That's close to 500 per day, and 1,000 per day if both ALFA and CHARLIE be blocking.

note

I plan to add additional nodes. Sorry, but I'm not sorry!

If I get to 2,000 points per day, with this I could deplete MONEYTEAM's earnings by 60,0000 per month. That should dent their earnings (and mine, but that's fine) by 3-4%.

In theory nothing prevents me from running 6 or 8 nodes, but for that I'd have to not lose money running them.

That's why I need analytics, to help me scale to as many nodes as possible, while still being able to cover expenses and attract nominators.

I can start blocking CRYPTOCALIBUR today, but there's no way to earn 10% for validators if I'm blocking 30 nodes.

So I can't "really" start blocking them now - I'd lose nominators, and then my nodes wouldn't get elected, and then everything would be in vain.

The good news here is they can't beat me. We both lose cMix points, but I don't have to make a profit for myself and - as pool operators - they do.

Next steps​

I don't even want to automate all that, but just copying cMix IDs, wallet IDs and on-chain IDs, and keeping it up to date takes a lot of time.

I plan to let this node run for 1-2 eras to calibrate it and estimate its earnings.

In parallel, I'll gather a list of pool nodes my node will be blocking. Depending on nominations (or a lack thereof), I may nominate the second node myself.

Economics​

Ideally I will block as many pool nodes as possible while staying at ~15% yield, but if I cannot block all of them I'll block as many as I can while making the pool nomination-worthy.

The idea is to grow the pool rather than block all pools right away. With just one or two validators, you can't block 50 validators and expect to be nomination-worthy. But I can have a low commission (say, 5%), block 10 validators, and remain commission worthy, and grow to more nodes which can then block more pool members.

After deducting my expenses, all earnigns will be unbound and sold at market price so that I can fund as many nodes as possible for as long as the community allows pools to operate (including my own). I've never sold xx coins I earned (which is why I have enough to nominate nodes on my own), but I can't scale the pool without funding its operations.

Summary​

The xx Network community is dominated by a cohort of "Marxxists" and a Validator Industrial Complex, so ethical community members have to find a way to stop them.

I'll post small updates on the first node below, and a new post once there's some progress regarding next steps above.

Follow me on X or revisit this blog for updates on this matter.

Additional nodes may be deployed sooner than expected. CHARLIE is awaiting nominations, and I've started working on BRAVO and DELTA.

Update 2​

I put online a guide for blocking large centralized pools. Find it at https://github.com/armchairancap/xx-pool-notes.

I plan to use it myself, but anyone who finds validation with 5 or more nodes objectionable can use it as a guide to easy and safe blocking of such bad actors.

entry.title: An attempt to address validator centralization problem
entry.summary: Plan B to annoy and deter
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • Plan B vs Plan A
  • Success criteria
  • How it's going to work
    • Process
  • Participation
  • Ethics of blocking (and not)
  • Will it work?

Introduction​

Recently I've written about various governance issues related to xx Network and other similar DAOs, such as Polkadot.

One big problem - not yet critical, but certainly one of the more significant problems on xx Network - is the issue of centralization and validator pools.

If you're interested, skim through these.

  • xx Network referendum (ID 27) on hiking the minimum validator stake
  • First pass of nomination-worthy xx Network validators (2025/01/04)
  • Why Polkadot governance sucks

A way to fix some of these problems within the community and without attempting to use the useless Democracy feature or hope that the Foundation does something was proposed in this post. I'll refer to it as Plan A.

I'm pleased to report that zero (0) people joined my attempt to execute Plan A. (Just as expected, I might add - it's not that different from Polkadot governance issues described above.)

This is about my next attempt and this time I'll do it myself because both those who are paid to do something about it and xx Network governance have failed me.

Plan B vs Plan A​

With Plan A, I tried to fund others to block IPs of pool nodes. That was actually a great plan, but the community sucks and/or is disengaged.

With Plan B, I'm just going to do it myself. The idea is the same: annoy and economically hurt centralizing sock-puppet node farmers. To do that, I need to build a farm of blocking validator nodes.

Success criteria​

I won't have enough nodes to make a big impact, so the effects of this won't be significant.

note

This is one of the reasons Plan A was great - it seeked to pay other validators who already have validator nodes ready.

If the Foundation had any sense, they would have not just rejected pools, but also fund a validator compensation program to pay everyone to execute Plan A on their behalf.

But I also don't need to make a big impact. It's enough to get noticed, so that is key: get noticed and raise awareness about the problem.

If I make some pool runners give up or change node names to "hide" them, that would be even better.

Blocking and annoying centralizing pools can't fix the problem: the moment I stop doing this, they'll start coming back. It has to be fixed through the currently failing governance and the Foundation.

I don't run either of those, so all I can do is make noise about outside the community, because inside I've already tried and failed.

I may run this experiment for weeks or months, depending on how I feel about it.

How it's going to work​

  • I will stand up one or more validator node(s)
  • Validator commission will be low (I don't know how low, but likely single-digit)
  • Validator nodes will block all obvious pool members (MONEYTEAM, etc.) so that they fail cMix rounds where my pool nodes participate
  • (TBD) Block all non-obvious pools. It takes time and effort to find them, so this is a low-priority item now. I'll go for the low-hanging fruit first.

Now, one node out of 370 won't matter. At most it will result in slightly more failed rounds (in pre-comp stage, for now at least) than normal and be barely noticeable.

But if I get to four active nodes, that's more than one percent of all validators and may become annoying to poo runners. Whether or not I'll get there depends on how many nominations I can get.

Eight nodes would be great, but that needs 1.7 MXX so it's harder to achieve. It may be possible if I target just one of the obvious pools (rather than all).

info

The new node(s) will have the on-chain ID ARMCHAIRANCAP/{NODE_NAME} and be nominated by ARMCHAIRANCAP and/or its proxy wallet ARMCHAIRANCAP/ArmchairAncap-Proxy-Wallet (6VMBPjeLHTM5qerw2zJCHs9t3VyeChf2MiE35MesLRxkb1wW).

If I make any changes, I'll update this information.

Process​

I will first stand up one node and run it for an era or two to calibrate it (see how much it earns, etc.).

Then I'll start blocking pools, observe my own earnings, the blocked pools' earnings and adjust my validator commission so that I can break even on hosting costs.

I figure that if my nodes fail 25% of all rounds I could break even. Obviously:

  • My oppportunity cost is the loss of profits which I would make by normally validating and nominating
  • I can't have 16 nodes that do that because I can't nominate 16 nodes on my own (that would take close to 3 MXX in nominations)
  • Even with a very low comission, my nodes may not yield enough to compensate for failed rounds, so I I may or may not attract other nominators
  • Because there won't be much (or any) profit, I'll sell all earnings the day they're made to pay for hosting

If my node(s) profit rate for nominators be very low (e.g. 8% APR), then they're unlikely to attract any nominators used to 16% or even higher APR.

Maybe I'll get to two or four or more nodes, but it's not likely.

Participation​

In Plan A, I wanted to pay people to block pools. That didn't work, but I'll be checking my chat space every now and then, to see if anyone wants to reach out.

Space participants may be asked to sign their Haven handle using their address in xx Network wallet, so that I don't have to guess how many XX tokens you have or if you really are a validator.

note

Why do I need to know how many tokens you have?

I actually don't care, but if you feel the need to discuss something from a validator or nominator perspective, I'll probably ask you to sign your Haven identify from your wallet, so that we can see if you're actually who you are or just an airdrop guy with 147.2753 XX in your wallet.

Here's what I'm interested in:

  • Prospective nominators (especially with 1 MXX or more) which would allow me to run 8 or more nodes
  • Help with identifying non-obvious pool runners
  • Validators and nominators interested in discussing ideas for fixing this problem

Ethics of blocking (and not)​

  • Is it ethical to block pools? Absolutely! They have a negative effect on the security of the network.

  • All validators should run less nodes than a cMix round has, which is five. If I get enough nominations, should I run more than four nodes? I think as long as it is obvious that others do it without declaring it (run more than 4 nodes, that is), there's no harm in me doing it transparently and with the sole purpose of stopping it. At any rate, I'd like to know what arguments those who don't think centralized pools are bad may have against my pool.

  • Is it ethical that the Foundation and the Technical Committee are not addressing this problem? I would say not, especially when it comes to paid officers of the Foundation.

Will it work?​

It doesn't matter. To me, the question is "should I try?" and the answer is "of course!"

That said, if it doesn't work out, this is probably the last thing I'll try before I become a "passive supporter" and move on to participating in functioning communities. I don't have to be here!

The Foundation, the Technical Committee and xx coin holders have the right and responsibility to manage the network. The Foundation should actively fight pools and use any means necessary to ban all wallets that belong to individuals with five or more nodes. Sadly, they're not doing it. (I would be less surprised if they banned my pool and I don't mind - that would bring my experiment to conclusion sooner.)

Depending on how this turns out (I don't mean "whether I find any nominators", but whether this issue gets addressed by the DAO or the Foundation) this may be the last thing I will do for the project with own money and time.

entry.summary: Potentially nomination-worthy xx Network validators as of early 2025
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • Update on validator doom
  • First pass
  • Notes
    • Example for 4CRYPTO
    • Possible improvements and take-aways
  • Appendix A - potentially nomination-worthy validators as of 2025/04/01

Introduction​

I'm not entirely convinced I should spend my time on this given the community of xx Network, but for what it's worth here's an improved list of potentially nomination-worthy xx Network validators as of January 4, 2025.

Compared to the lists of "known shit" and "potentially OK" nodes given in the previous post, this list improves on one minor shortcoming (mentioned in that past) which is that in that post I dropped nodes without at least 5 active nominators.

tip

Active nominators are those nominating a node in current era (day).

Inactive nominators seem to be all nominators (not just inactive, but both inactive and active!) nominating a node. If I'm wrong, then inactive plus active would be "all" nominators.

That meant that a validator with 50 nominators who get nominated by just 4 (active) nominators in this era, and be dropped from the list. Now I consider inactive nominators and look for at least five.

Update on validator doom​

Also already commented on in the previous post is the community doomers' prediction about "validator exodus" that was going to happen due to the still pathetically small new minimum validator stake of 15,000 XX (only $750-ish now).

Today there's more validators in waiting than there's been in many weeks - 26.

Not only there's no shortage of validators (although the slots should be cut to improve the quality and kick out the pools), but there's more validators than we had in December and the network is also more secure.

The stupidity of those community members has no limits! (Normally I'd say "ignorance", but you can check the forum - it was explained over and over again, on top of the fact that it shouldn't need to be explained in the first place!)

First pass​

Here's the first update in 2025.

note

This table does not container the list of recommended validators. It's just a starting point.

I exclude:

  • Names from my black list - any on-chain wallet IDs that pools use to identify themselves (CRYPTOCALIBUR and others)
  • Anyone without on-chain ID - easy way to eliminate pool trash
  • Anyone with the validator stake below the new minimum (15,000 XX that took effect 3 eras ago) - to avoid unexpected dropouts and avoid stranding
  • Anyone with less than 2 active or less than 5 inactive (Nom (I)) nominators - to avoid stranding your nominations
  • Anyone who takes more than 22.00% from node rewards
  • Any nodes whose predicted stake is or was more than 400,000 XX (i.e., "a lot")
info

Many nodes - both with and without on-chain ID - are controlled by hostile node runners who run the same or greater number of nodes than cMixx group size (five), adding risk to network. Those farm runners usually, but not always, have all of their nodes located in the same "geobin" i.e. a country or a region. If possible, avoid nominating more than 3 nodes from the same continent.

Nodes in Waiting - are excluded by default as a precaution, because Waiting is generally a high-risk area and may not be easy to safely "automate" recommendations (if anyone's nomination-worthy, why aren't they currently elected?). If you want to "hunt" for good opportunities there, you may manually inspect them.

Notes​

Go to Staking -> Overview or Staking -> Targets as well as the xx Network Explorer to perform additional checks.

Example for 4CRYPTO​

It's the first on the list, so I'll take that one as an example.

  • Decent own stake (48K XX), reasonably low commission
  • Its stats currently show consistent performance, steady and not excessive total nomination amount, no commission scamming (consistent 14%), which is all good
  • In Staking Targets, we see the node has 55 inactive nominators, which is great. Active are just two, but that's because both happen to be whale nominators
  • In the xx Network explorer we can go to Blockchain -> Transfers and see the node was "seeded" 1-2 years ago by probably laundering xx coins through MEXC, so it may be owned by an early validator (good) who's running a node farm (which would be bad, if the same person controls more than four)
  • Also in the explorer (Validator -> Metrics) it says on-chain identity is bad (there's just wallet name and nothing else)

Now, we could dig around to find more about those transactions, but at least it's not brazen like the trash from CRYPTOCALIBUR and MONEYTEAM, for example.

If you can find better nodes, choose better nodes. If not, this one may do - it's less bad than the nodes without on-chain ID and outright pool trash.

Possible improvements and take-aways​

I may make additional improvements such as:

  • consider points from last 7 eras
  • eliminate nodes with higher than 30% commission in any of most recent 180 eras
  • implement finer evaluation of on-chain ID (not just a binary Yes|No, but more similar to how Explorer rates validators in its metrics - maybe something like a scale from 1 to 5)
  • look into each nominator (wallet size, on-chain ID, number of nodes nominated by the validator...)

Even without those improvements, it's obvious that only 100 or so validators are worth nominating. Or, said differently, there are close to 200 that are not (this figure includes self-sufficient validators which aren't necessary malicious, but from a nominator's perspective, if a node runner is self-staked to 400,000 XX and takes a 40% commission, they're not nomination-worthy).

Considering this situation , it's not even feasible to make improvements to this node selection script - we'd have to drop even more nodes and having 50-60 nomination-worthy nodes out of 370 would be catastrophic: one would have to either crowd on the few good validators or nominate malicious (or generally not nomination-worthy) validators. Either of these choices is bad for the network.

Because of that I don't think I'll even consider publishing an updated list until the community does something to clean up that mess.

entry.title: Notes before the change of minimum validator stake on xx Chain
entry.summary: Notes before the change of minimum validator stake on xx Chain
entry.content:
• What changed, how and why
  • Why is 15K better than 1K
  • What now
  • What else needs to be done
  • Take-aways
  • What else should be done?
  • Update for era 1141
  • Appendix A - initial validator set for due diligence
  • Appendix B - potentially problematic nodes

What changed, how and why​

Those who follow xx Network are likely aware of the changes to the minimum validator stake.

Until era 1140 (today), validators could start validating with only 1,000 XX (less than $50).

The intent to introduce changes and "return" to the old limit were first approved in a referendum, and then a separate democracy vote approved the same change to chain variables deployed as a scheduled task set to increase the minimum stake to 15,000 XX on January 1, 2025. The first referendum also approves additional hikes in 2025 as necessary.

The minimum used to be 14,0000 XX back in 2021 when XX token was worth 4-5 times as much.

Why was it reduced to 1,000 XX? Because several loud community members who don't know anything about economics made more noise than the rest.

With the new hike the minimum stake is slightly higher, but only in XX coins. In US dollars, it's still almost 80% lower than the already low stake that the network used to have before.

Why is 15K better than 1K​

Because xx Network is as Proof of Stake network.

Validators must have a lot at stake to demonstrate their commitment to good, secure validation. It's nothing new.

The new minimum stake will make it harder (more expensive) to scam nominators. Starting with tomorrow's era it will cost 15 times as much to stand up a bunch of nodes, wait until they're nominated and elected, and then hike commission from the initial "below 20%" standard to 30% or 40% until nominators figure it out. Once they do, you spin up a new node with just $50 on it and start again.

It will also make node hoarding more expensive. You can still run a 20 node validator farm and undermine the security of the network, but for new adversaries that becomes 15 times more expensive.

The hike doesn't "solve" either of these problems, but it makes such behavior more expensive.

What now​

Some of the same xx community ignoramuses claim 15,000 XX is already unbearable for the "poor validators" who haven't been making profits from validation and now won't be able to afford 14,000 XX to be able to continue validating.

First, that's false, because they can keep going as long as they don't stop validating.

Second, if validating is not sustainable, compromising security of the network to inflate participation (and create more money-losing validators) isn't a good way to fix that problem.

Tomorrow's Phragmen election will be the first one which will prevent new entrants, but all the existing ones will be able to continue with their sub-15K XX stake.

Of course, the scammers have their little VM-based nodes ready to go: among the 24 nodes currently in Waiting only three seem regulars. I checked each prospective validator's wallet: all but three had 1,010 XX or less staked!

Waiting area during era 1140 (top):

Waiting area (bottom):

As they've already started validating but haven't been elected, I guess they may not be electable. Since they have no sizable nominators, I doubt any of those 21 can be elected anyway.

What else needs to be done​

xx Network suffers from the price of the token which makes validation unprofitable. That cannot (or at least: should not) be fixed by compromising the security of the network.

But the community is disengaged (I wrote about the same problem seen in other DAOs such as Polkadot) and 90% of active community members are either "degens" (price-focused speculators) or economic ignoramuses, which makes any improvements difficult.

The xx Foundation and Technical Committee members are staying out of these (seemingly "non-fundamental") governance discussions which is appropriate, but the end result is not satisfactory because meaningful improvements cannot happen in such environment. And more needs to be done.

Validator slots should be shrunk, but the groups I mentioned are against because it's (supposedly) "bad PR". By that logic adding 10 more slots should help (after all, there's as many as 24 nodes in waiting!), but they don't suggest that. I wonder why that is.

Take-aways​

note

15,000 XX is a laughable minimum validator stake ($750).

It takes much more on other Substrate networks and $10,000 to validate on Cellframe.

Keep that in mind before you start "proving" that a node owner with $750 staked on the node has more at staken than a node owner with $10,000 stakend on the node.

As we are about to enter era 1141, the hike seems entirely justified and obviously helpful - it doesn't need to "solve" anything, it just needs to make the undermining of security more expensive, which it does by a factor of 15.

In other words, this remains possible but now costs 15 times more, which is great.

What else should be done?​

  • Validator slots should be cut by 10 or 20 slots to ensure nodes require at least 300 K XX to get elected. Now a handful of nodes has less than 100 K XX (probably due to the pool scammers reshuffling those nodes which dropped), although more recently it was around 225 K XX. The network didn't need 370 nodes in the first place and they shouldn't have been added, so there should be no second thoughts about making necessary reductions and yet here we are, with dozens of people running many nodes with 1K XX validator stake on each...
  • An xx Postage bounty should be created and released as soon as ongoing bounties are delivered, to ensure real demand for tokens in second half of 2025. A RFC is on the forum and just needs to be worked on and released.
  • Various governance improvements are necessary

Governance needs to be improved to create more engagement both internally (validators, nominators), but also externally (with builders). That is mostly happening because of this stalemate between a disengaged majority, a loud (but grossly incompetent) minority of validators, and an unopinionated Foundation. I hope this will be resolved and improved in 2025.

Update for era 1141​

  • Just two (non-scammers) from the Waiting list got elected. As I've said above, I'm not sure if the scammers were even considered, given their non-elected status and a sub-15 K XX validator stake.
  • The next question is how many validators are still running with a sub-15K XX stake and do not have other problems? The answer to this question is: not many. These are nodes that don't have the validator stake of 15,000 XX or higher:
    • No on-chain ID: these are often pools or soft-scammers (see the pattern above) who don't care about validator reputation
    • Too few nominators (may be high risk, although in some cases you'll find an old-timer who is self-sufficient nd doesn't have 3rd party nominators). These can easily move tokens from the nomination to the validation wallet and get compliant instantly (i.e. buy 15K XX on MEXC and withdraw to validator wallet and in parallel unbond 15K from nominator wallet and later sell that on MEXC)
    • High commission (scammers and self-stakers) - not worth nominating (scammers) or don't need nominators because they're sufficient (self-stakers, sometimes also pools)
    • High nominator stake (example: 6ZNPt8…i17kW8 at the very top, over 1 MXX) - not worth nominating, don't need nominators and obviously loaded in any case

This list shows all nodes with "validator stake problem" active in era 1140 (most have other problems, too):

Let's take a look at several examples of nodes that look legit (no other challenges or reasons), but don't have enough staked by the validator. That is, on the surface their only problem is a low own stake. I'll review such nodes from only the last 20 lines (for easier viewing from this position):

  • MONEYTEAM_ - pool trash (there are others, such as UNITED EARTH) - getting rid of them would be a blessing!
  • NARAYANA SUPRAMATI - multi-year validator who scored well over 100 K XX in the Foundation sponsorship and probably has enough funds to run multiple nodes (e.g. VANILLA). This guy is far from tapping out - he'll be fine!
  • DIPRO - the same with regard to the Foundation sponsorship.
  • 6aug5i…kz3J21 - the same with regard to the Foundation sponsorship. Also, has a relatively high commission (22%) for such a low-earning node (barely earns 140 XX per era - probably just an undersized VM). Been around for almost 1,000 eras, but too busy to set an on-chain ID or set node commission to levels commersurate with the el cheapo VM it's running on.
  • 6X83J3…FNvajd - hasn't done a single cMixx round in last 30 days. Why is this guy even elected?
  • BLOCKBARD - Just $50 short of the new minimum. He's been around for a while and doesn't pay for the node from earnings (since none are being sent to an exchange)
  • All others from the last 20 lines have other problems or don't need nominators (e.g. self-nominated such as 6ZvBHA…DgpQSp).

In conclusion, it is true that many nodes don't have the minimum validator stake, but the validators above aren't the only ones I've looked at and I'm yet to find that mythical "honest struggling validator". If you can't be bothered to set an on-chain ID (not to mention other, more meaningful things), run at 22% commission earning 140 XX per day, etc. it's hard to be taken seriously and expect sympathy.

Appendix A - initial validator set for due diligence​

These aren't recommended, but merely meet some basic criteria:

  • 22.00% or lower validator commission rate
  • more than 15K XX minimum stake
  • more than 35,000 cMix points (in era 1140, in this case)
  • obvious pool members have been pre-dropped, but many need to be manually checked
tip

Ideally we'd check for more than 35,000 cMix points and lower than 22% commission in 180 most recent eras, for example.

From the below list I'd drop the following before doing other checks:

Appendix B - potentially problematic nodes​

These shouldn't be a priori excluded, but are suspicious.

  • high commission
  • pool trash (CRYPTOCALIBUR, MONEYTEAM, UNITED EARTH, etc.) and non-mixing nodes (XX FOUNDATION are Foundation nodes that always get elected, but don't run cMixx)
  • too few or too many nominators (but see Note below)
  • low own stake (could stop validating, become unelectable, and leave your nomination inactive)
  • high nomination value (which means a lower ROI)
  • no on-chain ID (potential scammers, pool drones)
note

"Too few" nominators isn't a sure sign of a problem because that figure is the number of "staking nominators in current era" whereas the node may have more nominators but not assigned by Phragmen in this era. That would require additional checks. A self-sufficient runner (e.g. ANODE2 self-staked with 500 K XX) may have no nominators for obvious and perfectly legitimate reasons.
