entry.title: How to buy WXX(BRC20)
entry.summary: Buying WXX(BRC20)
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • Why buy WXX(BRC20)
  • Buying process
    • Transactions
  • Tips for degens
  • Why is this cool?
  • Next steps

Introduction​

The idea is to crowdsource funds for a CrowdSwap liquidity pool for WXX (BRC20), which is a wrapped WXX (ERC20), which itself is wrapped XX on Ethereum.

Since BNB and Ethereum are similar, re-wrapping WXX (ERC20) - issued by the xx Foundation - is secure and easy.

Now some of the WXX (ERC20) that's available on Uniswap will be re-wrapped as WXX (BRC20), as I understand it, making it easy to move liquidity between DEXes. Pancake swap will be added later.

Read about it here.

warning
  • If you're a US citizen, US resident or from a weird country, don't even try (there's KYC)
  • Payment can be done today or on February 23, but "delivery" will happen after (February 25?) (see the link above)

This is not a recommendation or advice. Do your own research.

The sale ends on February 24, 2025.

Why buy WXX(BRC20)​

My interest here is simple:

  • I'm a believer in DEX
  • xx token hasn't been able to get listed at large centralized exchanges because its privacy options make it look fishy (as if it's a privacy coin, which it is not)
  • Historically DEXes have had a problem with liquidity. Newest one don't, but these still do, so they need help
  • There are rewards (funded by xx Foundation), so it's not just free donation of liquidity - there are benefits for those who participate to help with liquidity of decentralized XX markets

Buying process​

Read the link above for the details, but ignoring the conditions (very important, so you need to read the link), the "doing" part goes like this:

  • You need at least the equivalent of $105 or so in crypto, as the minimum purchase is $100 and there are other fees involved
  • Pick a wallet which can work with https://app.crowdswap.org and connect it
  • In user profile, fill in a name, email, and pick username for Crowdswap (I think that's mostly for referrals, there's no login or password)
  • Find the xx private sale for WXX on Opportunity page
  • You need to agree and "sign" an agreement to be able to actually perform a transaction
  • If you're not in one of trouble countries, a simple KYC may be necessary (for me it was very a painless process, but it may depend on your IP or who knows what)

Transactions​

Metamask was a frustrating experience for UDST (I could have used Ethereum, but I didn't want to pay their gas fees), so I gave up and used BNB chain in another wallet.

tip

The easiest way is to send ETH or BNB to a native ETH or BNB address wallet, and buy with that.

If you're looking for cheapest fees, maybe try sending USDT(BNB) or BNB tokens to a BNB wallet.

I don't know what networks are supported, so I can't really tell for sure. Please check on your own and test with a small transaction before you send $100 or more.

I screwed up at first - I sent USDT to a BNB wallet, but didn't have any native coins to do anything that, so I also had to send some dust for the gas. Stupid...

Once that was solved, and all the steps from the list above done, I was able to pay:

That was close to 2000 WXX(BRC20), about the same price that one can get on MEXC (more on that later).

note

"WXX" in this screenshot is the address tag.

WXX(BRC20) will be paid once the private sale ends.

The wallet asked for a confirmation:

With that I successfully completed the first "test" transaction in this private sale!

I paid the following transaction fees from the wallet:

  • 0.0000x BNB to sign the purchase agreement ("empty" transaction)
  • 0.000x BNB purchase coins (USDT on BNB transferred to the seller)

One BNB is around $370 so it was very cheap. I don't know how much it'd cost on Ethereum, but probably more.

The fee I paid to send USDT(BNB) and BNB tokens from a CEX to the wallet isn't shown, as it's collected at the source.

Currently XX/USDT at MEXC is the same as this, so there's no immediate financial benefit to buying, but I plan to buy more because I want to provide liquidity for the XX pairs on decentralized exchanges.

Tips for degens​

To fund my purchases of WXX(BRC20) I may sell some of my "non-wrapped" XX coins.

As others will likely do the same, it's is expected that the price of XX/USDT on MEXC (the biggest XX CEX market) will remain the same as the crowdsale price.

So... Do not buy WXX (or XX) thinking it's some crazy pump & dump scheme. It's not.

Why is this cool?​

  • Liquidity for decentralized XX token markets
  • Users new to xx Network will become familiar with DEX and cMixx (very important, as opposed to airdrops)
  • Affordable campaign to reach out to new users
  • Technical simplicity (uses existing XX-to-WXX contract on Ethereum)

Downsides:

  • As long as the sale lasts, it puts a ceiling on the price of xx token, because the sale is based on the fixed priced of xx token (I guess it had to be done that way), so MEXC and other markets will be "stuck" in a narrow range and miss the ongoing bubble. I don't care, but some folks do.

I think overall it's a very positive development for xx token.

Next steps​

These DEXes (Uniswap, Crowdswap, and in the future Pacakeswap) lessen the need for T1/T2 CEX.

note

Next-generation DEXes will do even more to balance power beteween crypto projects and CEXes. Keep an eye on that!

As incentives and rewards are available and I'm not looking to sell or exit XX, buying some WXX (BRC20) wasn't a difficult decision to make.

I also used this opportunity as an excuse to learn about the process of buying using the minimum (US$100-ish) amount. I'll repeat this multiple times with larger amounts before the sale ends.

The price of XX (and WXX) will remain "stuck" for 2 months, but benefits are going to be higher than this small inconvenience.

I hope in 2025 XX also makes it to a next-generation DEX (one of those that will appear on Supra, for example). Spreads will become so narrow and liquidity "unlimited"! At that big CEX listings will become uninteresting. But until then and even after then, we need choices and competition.

entry.title: Why Polkadot governance sucks
entry.summary: No, it's not working exceptionally well
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • Symptoms
  • Why Polkadot governance sucks?
  • What should Polkadot do?
  • Take-away

Introduction​

I'll make this one short because there aren't many such opinions.

Polkadot is a DAO, and has governance built-in.

It is actually very well done and saves a lot of time to anyone building a blockchain-based DAO - xx Network uses it as well.

What, then, is the problem?

Symptoms​

My knowledge of Polkadot is somewhat limited - I haven't participated and used it for years.

But I've followed it closely this year and I've used Kusama, for example.

xx Network is also a DAO and uses essentially the same stack, so there isn't much an xx Network user needs to learn infrastructure-wise. What is needed to understand is observation - seeing how it's used, what users think about it, and so on.

Based on those observations, I've noticed several symptoms:

  • Claims that "whale" projects are milking the system by (easily) getting (undeserved) funding
  • Opinions that many DAO-funded projects suck
  • Dissatisfaction with how the DAO "democracy" works in practice
  • Observations on disengaged participation (example: people nominate, but don't vote on anything even as they login to wallet to collect rewards or transfer funds)
  • All sorts of stupid ideas are getting traction (and possibly DAO-approved funding - this I estimate based on seeing how much traction uterrly senseless ideas get in the Polkadot community)
info

This proposal proposed a bounty to fund a lawsuit against a "notable" community member Giotto De Filippi who scammed the DAO with a fake memecoin proposal that was funded with 1 MM DOT.

Clowns...

Sadly, it didn't pass - probably because most of those with fat DOT wallets wouldn't want undue attention and similar reactions to their own proposals... ::

Here's another gem:

Literally every 3 days I have to vote on 20-30 new proposals. This is just so time consuming, so I just open the ICP voting webtab on a side screen, vote “YES” on the about 25 new proposals about every 3 days, not even read the stuff anylonger, while continuing doing other work on my main screen.

In other words, these are the same weaknesses that we can observe in Western democracies.

Shockingly, or perhaps not at all, some still claim the DAO is functioning "exceptionally well". I guess I'd claim that as well if I was milking the system to my satisfaction.

The obvious truth is governance is not functioning well at all.

Why Polkadot governance sucks?​

Here's why:

  • the DAO destroys, rather than creates, competition [1]
  • the DAO picks winners
  • the DAO thereby creates losers (once a winner for is picked, all others are fxxed because unless they're vastly superior they stand no chance of charging for their service and their funding dries up)
  • the DAO causes inflation with such unnecessary and excessive spending
  • the DAO hurts the ecosystem because it retards free markets that let users vote with their (subscription) tokens. Services that would normally compete and pass their costs (plus some extra value) to users siply don't appear because of this more-or-less "winner takes all" system created by the DAO
  • Everyone gets to vote, and that includes self-serving cronies, ignoramuses and people who have no idea about anything (many may be underage, although their stakes are usually (and thanfully) too low to matter)

[1] There's competition in the Art of Proposals and vote marshaling, all right, just not in projects and services

My forked (upstream was funded by the DAO, I suppose?) project for token-gated access to Web3 apps is a good example. I think the idea is great and use cases many (as I explain in that blog post). If you look around, you'll see there have been many asks for this functionality. For example, Discord channels could be gated the same way based on one's holdings of tokens, assets or NFTs. Even Web2 forums could use it.

Yet, no one maintains such an app for Polkadot, and "small" Web3 sites don't even exist. It's a simple app and people funded by the DAO like to apply for $500 grants rather than smaller projects that general users could use to create a "no-code" Web3 experience or bridge Web2 apps to Web3.

Another example is various "major" Web sites in the Polkadot ecosystem. They're barely useful and often bloated (more "features" means more funds).

Anyway, how to fix it? The same way it's done in Western democracies: by educating the voter, which is a centuries-long process and not something that will happen in our lifetime.

For a comparison, I think xx Network works better. It's not good enough, but it's not a disaster either.

Why is that? I think it's because it has better people, which is how it was bootstrapped. This isn't to say Polkadot has bad people, but it's been a while and they don't seem as engaged in the DAO as the original xx Network team.

xx Network is more of a constitutional republic, while Polkadot is a democracy. Even though both use the same code, the latter is already corrupt beyond repair. The USA vs. the European Union.

What should Polkadot do?​

To be honest, I don't know how they can get enough votes to do anything but keep destroying what the founder(s) and early volunteers built.

note

On that note, those who "volunteered" didn't do it for free. Most had interest in making DOT and KSM appreciate in value. Today's DAO leeches are nothing like the early volunteers.

If you're contributing only as long as they pay you, you're more akin to a bureaucrat or public sector worker. Not everyone is, but most are.

Some minor improvements can be made - for example they recently modified inflation rate, which is now less stupid. But I don't think majority of voters would support any proposal that significantly impacts their disproportional or undeserved benefits. It's like expecting public sector unions to support budget cuts.

Usually a short-term solution - or interim solution - is to have a benevolent populist dictator. Someone like Linus Torvalds, who is liked enough to be given extra power. That's great as long as the person is around, and goes south quickly as soon as he gets replaced by a lesser person.

In addition to that being a short-term solution, at this point it the DAO can't even do that because there's no mechanism for this to happen. It's wrongly bootstrapped/wired.

Whether it's done by a dictator or a powerful group, here's what I think would fix a lot of problems:

  • Burn all excess treasury funds not required for basic expenses plus some emergency reserve
  • Eliminate funding of most projects excluding essential infrastructure (such as a bare bones blockchain explorer) and let them compete for paying customers on their own
  • Reorganize funding so that it's split by categories and done only over very short term (3 to 6 months - just enough to let them do a PoC and be able to seek funding). Then modify voting so that those who support funding be mildly on the hook (use long-term conviction proportional to cost of spending they choose to support)
  • Strengthen the role of on-chain identity to bring more transparency to decision-making and spending
  • Extend unstaking period to months and years, so that it becomes lucrative to vote with higher conviction and divest slower

Each of these items is impossible to happen, but even if it did, it wouldn't last long: cronies and ingnoramuses would start taking over again, possibly starting at the top (with someone who'd undo everything even faster).

Take-away​

The same tool used by different people can lead to a very different result.

The Polkadot DAO is failing, but that doesn't mean it's worse than other crypto projects. Most other projects are much worse, which is why I'm happy to be part of the greater Polkadot ecosystem and xx Network in particular.

Real and sustainable change requires education, which takes decades and maybe even centuries. We won't live long enough to see it.

Meanwhile, those of us who care have to do what we can to slow that decline and make our projects stay around long enough until most "DAOists" learn to act in common interest.

entry.title: Top PQ crypto coins for 2025 (according to Altcoin Daily)
entry.summary: Top PQ coins? What does that even mean?
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • Cellframe (CELL)
    • Opinion on CELL
  • Quantum Resistant Ledger Markets (QRL)
    • Opinion on QRL
  • Ozone Chain (OZO)
    • Opinion on QLR
  • Comments on comments in the X thread
    • QAN blockchain platform (QANX)
    • QuantumEVM
    • Other coins in the X thread
  • xx Network (XX)
    • xx Chain (xx token)
    • cMixx
    • xx Network development
  • Final thoughts
  • Addendum

Introduction​

The Altcoin Daily posted a pumping "suggestion" about the top quantum-computing resistant coins for 2025:

  • CELL
  • OZO
  • QRL

What does that even mean? Nothing, really.

It's a low-effort post (maybe even an AI-generated shitpost) meant to gain followers and have the shills post their nonsense comments.

They post a the top three symbols from CMC's list of PQ coins with highest market capitalization, and then those who are involved in PQ-related projects need to explain to "investors" which of them is "the best" and why:

And in Altcoin Daily's post CELL is listed a the top - in alphabetical order - but QRL is listed before OZO, which may be due to OZO paying less or nothing for that post.

But still, what does this mean?

Every few days I hear some speculator asking how xx Network compares to this or that coin, why xx Network isn't "pumping", and such.

Everyone should read and answer for themselves, but I admin I haven't done it as well because I thought most of it is nonsense and a waste of time. Fundamentally, privacy means inconvenience and extra cost (in time or hardware or software), so privacy-focused solutions are not easy to sell.

But now this is a topic that we are expected to have an opinion about, so let's take a look at what these projects are, their claims, are and whether they should be compared with xx Network (and if so, how).

note

"Post-quantum" and "quantum-resistant" means unbreakable by Cryptographically Relevant Quantum Computer (CRQC) systems aka Quantum Computers. So PQC means resistant to attacks by known CRQCs.

Cellframe (CELL)​

From their white paper:

By design, Cellframe’s architecture is a structure with a dual-layer sharding. The first layer (heterogeneous layer) can launch customizable subchains and tokens. On the second layer (homogeneous layer), subchains are organized in Cells. Due to interoperability features we plan to build an ecosystem of services where every app (or dapp) will have an opportunity to exchange information with another app in a p2p manner.

This is nice, but as always, I don't like this rebuilding of the wheel.

Everyone has a dApp platform... Including xx Chain (and all Substrate-based chains). Even Polkadot - a top coin - doesn't have enough apps (and their ecosystem has hundreds), and can't sustain a stablecoin because there's not enough liquidity compared to "the top dogs". What are the chances these guys can make it?

Or take this example from the sme white paper:

The main idea of Cellframe is multiple subchains, containing Plasma (any blockchain element) inside of syngeneic Cells (shards).

Does this sound like Polkadot's parachains (which xx Netowrk could adopt and use)? Does

And from the roadmap page, here's what is yet to be done:

  • Release of mechanism for stakers to delegate keys to validators using Cellframe Dashboard (xx Chain has Simple Staking, adopted from the Polkadot ecosytem)
  • EVM-compatible service (xx Chain could adopt it from Polkadot ecosystem)
  • They're developing own format of interchangeable tokens (besed on the numbers, such as CF-20, it's similar to Ethereum's)
  • Interoperability protocol, bridging with other blockchains (PolkadotSDK has several and more will be added faster than Cellframe can do it. xx Chain uses two token bridges (XRP and Ethereum))
note

They just got two-way bridging done, while wrapped XX coin is listing on DEXes (WXX(ERC20), WXX(BEP20)), so even with that they're still building out these relatively basic integrations while Substrate-based coins do this with relative ease.

xx Network doesn't even focus on the coin itself and has most of what it needs (chain integrations-wise). Additionally, it costs relatively little to develop, test and maintain.

As you can see the main issue I have with Cellframe is they are reinventing the wheel.

Examples from two recent releases, 5.3-327 and 5.3-277:

  • Issue with serialization/deserialization of data in JSON-RPC
  • Fork auto-resolution mechanism
  • Functionality of the tx_history-addr command

This is what happens when you decide to build the wheel from scratch. Ongoing and yet-to-be discovered security and other problems.

If you're META or Ethereum, maybe you can pull it off. If you're not, well...

Interestingly Cellframe runs a VPN, with the following pricing:

This reminds me of Nym and the risks I mentioned there (read it to get the idea, if you don't already have it)...

Although Cellframe and KelVPN are products from the same parent company, “Demlabs,” KelVPN is a separate project with a dedicated developer team. KelVPN is the first service built on Cellframe, which is a blockchain platform for different decentralized services. KelVPN is based on the Cellframe parachain and uses Cellframe SDK.

For a comparison, search this blog for "postage" or take a look at this post: xx Network is a DAO and plans to provide paid mixnet servics in what I think is a much better way (no "parent company" and associated risks, crypto-only payments with XX coin obtained from a DEX or CEX).

The FAQs gives the following examples of services that could run on Cellframe:

  • decentralized VPNs and CDNs
  • messengers and social networks
  • voting

Messaging has worked on xx Network for years and is the focus of the network. Voting has also undergone a lot of research (see Votexx) and implemented for Worldcoin.

It appears some Cellframe services (or "ideas" of services) overlap with Nym's, others with other projects (e.g. StorJ for CNDs), and some with xx Network (except that xx Network has had them for a while and are xx Network's main focus).

PQ-wise, Cellframe uses CRYSTALS-Dilithium and Falcon. I haven't looked into these yet.

Opinion on CELL​

It reminds me of Nym, but with some Ethereum features (basically nothing that one can't do on PolkadotSDK chains).

While some use cases seem similar to xx Network's, they don't really have those apps because they've been busy rebuilding the wheel.

info

One of the nice things about Cellframe is validators must be staked with 10,000 CELL. Currently that is over US$10,000.

For a comparison, today you can start validating on xx Network with $60. How is that even possible?

Well, the xx Network community has its fair share of socialists who think everyone should be able to do what they want without anything at stake. That's easy to change and is in the process of being changed as I write this, but it's crazy that this was made possible int the first place.

I made a similar (positive) comment regarding Nym's approach to validation in the post about Nym.

Quantum Resistant Ledger Markets (QRL)​

QRL has been around for a long time (longer than xx Network, six years vs three for xx Network), and has a decent following.

QRL's mission is a PQ chain.

Provide enterprise grade security to the blockchain space with the future quantum threat in mind.

This is what they have at CMC:

The Quantum Resistant Ledger (QRL) is a 'fully quantum resistant blockchain network, using PQ-CRYPTO recommended/IETF standardized cryptography'. The QRL utilizes a hash-based eXtended Merkle Tree Signature Scheme (XMSS) instead of ECDSA, which is reportedly vulnerable to quantum attacks and found in many other blockchain projects.

What's that about ECDSA? Well, NIST announced its depreciation:

.. of RSA, ECDSA, and EdDSA encryption algorithms by 2030, with a full disallowance by 2035.

OMG, we're screwed!!!

Or maybe not.

Here's what current draft of this deprecation plan says (as of 2024/12/14):

Up to 11 years to go, and that's if you depend on ECDSA and must use it. xx Chain does not have to use ECDSA signatures.

info

Bitcoin uses [256-bit ECDSA](https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Elliptic_Curve_Digital_Signature_Algorithm:

For bitcoin these are Secp256k1 and SHA256(SHA256()) respectively.

The web site says the their chain uses XMSS, a NIST-approved post-quantum secure digital signature scheme.

Similarly to Ozone Chain (below), they use lattice-key storage.

QRL uses RandomX, a proof of work (PoW) algorithm based on random code execution.

They claim two audits, by red4sec and x41 D-sec, which is very nice but also expensive. As I recall xx Network had one audit, in 2021, for example.

They have post-quantum addresses developed in-house, which xx Network also has (Sleeve, mentioned further below in the xx Network section).

In terms of plans, here's what they have on their site on next generation of QRL:

codenamed Zond, is introducing key features such as web3 compatibility and a proof-of-stake protocol with Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM) smart contract support. QRL Zond integrates post-quantum secure methods with Ethereum architecture, offering a secure platform for future applications in decentralized finance (DeFi).

EVM support is nice and PolkadotSDK chains can also run EVM in addition to its own native ecosystem with hundreds of applications, but that is not the focus of xx Network (cMixx is).

Opinion on QRL​

With its focus on chain and wallets, QRL is a "PQ-Litecoin", if you will. Monero is also a PoW chain, I don't see that QRL focuses on privacy, so I changed that to "PQ-Litecoin".

Having Sleeve-like wallet generator and two audits is very helpful for coin-based use cases.

xx Network is a messaging forcused PQ project. Wallets (created with Sleeve) are PQ-secure and the chain itself is very likely going to become PQ-secure because Polkadot DAO is very well funded with a vibrant ecosystem (if you don't understand the value of PolkadotSDK to xx Chain, see this post).

To summarize: QRL has some advantages over xx Chain, but they may not be sustainable. On the other hand, it has no meaningful applications except the coin itself, while xx Network focuses on PQ-mixnet services.

Ozone Chain (OZO)​

From their CMC introduction:

Ozone chain uses quantum random numbers (QRN) and post-quantum cryptography (PQC) ... an architectural decision has been made to use PQC for inter-node communications, while being quantum-resistant at the same time.

warning

Easily confusable with BOZO (also a coin)!

Ozone's QRNG has also passed the NIST SP 800-22 tests. That's nice.

Ozone claims three PQ-related features:

  • QRNG - quantum process-based random number generator
  • QKD - quantum key distribution
  • PQC - post-quantum cryptography that uses lattice-based cryptography (whichis different from cMixx, for example). Resistant to attack by both classical and quantum computers

I'm not sure how QKD works and why they need it. It's a secret:

  1. Setup quantum tunnels between your node and other nodes Contact ozonechain developers in its official discord channel for node admins.

Wait, so is this a permissioned network as far as validation is concerned? Let's see (on the same page):

The new validator will be accepted by the network after a period of 6 hours mentioned by epochlength in the genesis file is passed and if it received the votes from a majority (above 50%) of existing validators within the 6 hours period.

It appears to be permissioned because you can't become a candidate without the developers' help and once you do become a candidate, there's no market mechanism (such as NPoS on Substrate-based chains including xx Chain). NPoS isn't perfect, but this one is ... mysterious. You need to get permitted, and then lobby the existing validators to join in. That's strange, and maybe more "centralizing" than NPoS.

Also on the same page:

  1. Setup quantum tunnels between your node and the newly created nodes Contact ozonechain developers in its official discord channel for node admins.

If Discord is down, you can't become a validator.

About PQC in Ozone:

CRYSTALS-Kyber. CRYSTALS (Cryptographic Suite for Algebraic Lattices) comprises two lattice-based cryptographic primitives:

  • Kyber, a CCA-secure KEM, and
  • Dilithium, a strongly EUF-CMA secure digital signature algorithm.

This isn't comparable to xx Chain (see other comments about PolkadotSDK-based chains), which don't claim PQC, and users of xx Network's cMixx mixnet aren't directly impacted by lack of chain-level PQC.

note

If xx Chain were to be compromised by a CRQC, it could indirectly compromise cMixx as well, but in obvious ways - such as large and/or sustained turnover in validators - which would likely also impact other Substrate-based chains unless the attacker focused solely on xx Chain. I can't think of non-obvious ways that PQ-compromise of xx Chain would impact the security of cMixx. That doesn't mean there are none, of course.

Ozone's QRNG sounds like snake oil to me. You can read about it here. The reason I say that is the illustration implies custom hardware, so unless everyone has one, these random numbers may be emitted from a centralized source ("Ozone Foundation" or some 3rd party beacon?). If it's centralized, it's not good.

info

PolkadotSDK-based chains can include Drand Bridge Pallet, a Drand-to-Substrate bridge.

There's also dVRF, Supra's decentralized verifiable randomness service, which is mature and used in production by dozens of projects:

Supra dVRF solves on-chain randomness for Web3 at large, not just a few networks. We’re already on 27 networks like Aptos, Arbitrum, Avalanche, Ethereum, Optimism, and Polygon.

Supra's dVRF is available on Supra's L1, but as you can see from this quote above, other networks/chains use it in absence of a better native dVRF.

It doesn't appear that xx Chain needs a PQ VRF, as there are no applications (such as gambling or gaming) which require such randomness. When it becomes necessary xx Chain will likely use a PQ DVRF such as Drand Bridge Pallet (if it's PQ or after it becomes PQ).

Ozone is EVM compatible and has half a dozen apps (DEX, memes, games) - all unrelated to what xx Network does.

My take: it's a PQ EVM platform on a small EVM-compatible chain. There are dozens of EVM-compatible chains that are larger and permissionless.

Ozone's transactions are currently around 4,000/day, while xx Chain has around 600 and many of them are nomination/validation-related, so it has to be said that xx Chain has very few transactions. Why is that?

The action on xx Network hapens on cMixx (mixnet), which is free to use and doesn't require any coins (XX or other). On the other hand, many of Ozone's transactions may be DEX and memecoin traffic.

Block times are 5 and 6 seconds, respectively, but in the case of xx Chain that's not realy pertinent to almost any relevant use case (as I've mentioned, the action is happening on cMixx).

Opinion on QLR​

Ozone's PQ-related features look nice, but it's a tiny platform where you may be PQ-ready, but can be excluded or banned at any time. The threat of that is probably higher than the threat of CRQC...

Comments on comments in the X thread​

Shills of course flooded the thread with stupid comments, which I break down in two groups: on-topic (QANX, QuantumEVM) and off-topic (the rest, as of writing this post).

QAN blockchain platform (QANX)​

One of the comments mentioned this coin.

I won't waste time on it - it's a company owned platform that has to turn a profit (got $15 million from VCs) or else.

30+ team members spread across 10+ countries

Features:

  • PQ (CRYSTALS-Dilithium) - different from messaging focused PQ stack used by cMixx, but PolkadotSDK chains may end up with the same chain PQ algo down the road
  • EVM and other VMs - same as PolkadotSDK-basaed chains
  • Proof-of-Randomness (PoR) algorithm - see earlier comments on randomness
  • 1600 TPS - less than xx Chain can do, but even with xxPostage xx Chain won't need many transactions
  • Enterprise focus - okay... They run private chains for paying customers

Alpine Esports, a Group Renault brand, and inter alia in the Formula 1® Esports Series signed QANplatform as its Official Blockchain Partner.

It's a chain-focused token that won't make it without (eventually) government or EU handouts. You can see a hint of that here:

First EU country implemented QAN’s quantum-resistant technology in March 2024.

If you have to burn your PQ budget with a EU startup, that's the place to go!

It doesn't seem their public network has launched (or they don't update their docs). According to their roadmap there's no public mainnet yet and they're still collecting validator applications (there's a Google Docs form on the same page).

Users interested in xx Network's use case (confidential messaging) won't use this one. But they may get some business from enterprise users running private PQ-based chains.

info

I believe enterprises who want to pay can reach out to the xx Foundation for licensing and support.

The xx Network stack is possibly less expensive and very permissively licensed.

As far as chain features are concerned, Supra (which I hold) will cush these guys.

QuantumEVM​

This is the same thing as QANON... sorry, QANX: Ethereum with PQ patches.

xx Network isn't in PQ EVM or blockchain business, so there's noth much to compare, but aside from that, they don't have anything in place: it seems they're trying to ICO now, so they may be a year from a functioning decentralized mainnet, and even then they won't have anything similar to cMixx.

I commented here.

Other coins in the X thread​

I saw a bunch of coins/chains mentioned in the thread. I checked five, and three of them were random shitposts pumping loser coins that have nothing in terms of PQ readiness.

Two I've heard of, and was able to find something PQ-related:

  • Algorand (ALGO) - partially ready (uses FALCON), but VRF is vulnerable and will have to be swapped out (same as PolkadotSDK-based chains). No sign of PQ in wallets (addresses), though.
  • Hedera (HDR) - doesn't seem ready in any way. This post explains that. No signs of any PQ features.

As you can see, they're very "L1-focused" (similar to the three coins higlighted by Altcoin Daily). Algorand's addresses and signatures may be in trouble and Hedera's probably, too.

In any case, they don't appear focused on PQ messaging, so who cares.

xx Network (XX)​

First, each stack of xx Network should be separately analyzed. I'm not a cryptographer,

xx Chain (xx token)​

XX is the native token of xx chain.

xx Chain is a Substrate- (or, PolkadotSDK-based) chain which is PQ-ready. Whazzit mean?

It means that once PolkadotSDK is PQ-ready, xx Chain will be updated to be ready as well.

Does that means all PolkadotSDK chains will be PQ-ready? Not really.

xx Validators - and all who used Sleeve have PQ-ready wallet addresses and PQ-ready wallet pass phrase.

Sleeve ... derives the quantum-secure wallet, which is not currently used, but will be necessary in the future in order to rollover existing non quantum secure wallets into quantum secure wallets.

Sleeve uses WOTS+ and has a defined path to upgrade the chain to support WOTS+ signatures in transactions and user accounts. From the repo:

uses a WOTS+ key as the underlying quantum secure key. After the WOTS+ key is generated, we save the quantum secure public key (PK). This public key will be used as the Wallet address when full quantum secure capabilities are implemented in the future.

Sooo.... xx Network is in a very good place.

Do these other PQ coins have such wallets? As far as I can tell, QRL may have it. Those who don't won't become ready without migrating existing wallets.

Any non-PQ ready chains as well as PQ-ready without PQ addresses will have to:

  • manually move all assets to a new quantum secure wallet (address)
  • migrate blockchain signature system to WOTS+ (or similar)

xx Chain wallets with Sleeve-generated wallets won't need to do any of this.

cMixx​

The real PQ action - and why xx Network probably shouldn't be compared with those coins - is in cMixx.

cMixx employs the following cryptographic primitives:

  • XChaCha20: Length is 256 bits. Used for encrypting message payloads.
  • Blake2b: Length is 256 bits. Used as part of key generation, key expansion, identity generation, and identification codes. Used to combine Diffie–Helman and SIDH keys after key integration.
  • HMAC-SHA256: Length is 256 bits. Message HMACs.
  • Diffie–Hellmen: Length is 3072 bits. Discrete log-based component of key negotiation.
  • SIDH: Length of public key is 3024 bits. Quantum resistant component of key negotiation in theoriginal cMix. In cMixx (current implementation) SIDH was replaced by CSIDH.

xx Network development​

I don't speak for xx Network, but based on what's happening now and what I think will happen in the future:

  • xx Chain is PQ-ready and will adopt PQ enhancements from PolkadotSDK which will surely come about. Some enhancements (such as provable decentralized randomness) are already available, it's just that they're not necessary
  • cMixx is the core service of xx Network and what sets it apart from these three coins. There are integrations for mixing wallet transactions (e.g. with Metamask), private and confidential ID lookups (Worldcoin) and Haven, a reference messaging platform. You can look at the current grants (on forum.xx.network) and see all of them are related to improving cMixx. One of

I don't maintain this comparison, but see here how Haven (and cMixx in general) compares against other encrypted messengers.

Final thoughts​

The Altcoin Daily post is meaningless. But obviously "it worked" because it made me spend time on writing this post.

While all three coins (CELL, OZO, QRL) have PQ-ready chains, from what I can see not all have PQ addresses.

Some have heavily centralized validation while others are backed by commercial entities (and therefore centralized). These factors present greater risks than CRQC.

None of them focus on messaging. Cellframe mentions it as a use case, but that's far from having anything usable and in production.

xx Network's blockchain is already sufficiently PQ-resistant, and given Polkadot DAO's resources, will be ready before it becomes important. xx Network addresses generated with Sleeve are considered secure.

xx Network's main service, cMixx, is also PQ-resistant. It's been in production for years (try xx Network Haven here), and has integrations unrelated to XX coin. In fact cMixx mixnet can be used for mixing wallet RPC calls of any coin (see Proxxy) and it can be done for free.

Even when it comes to blockchain, xx Network has PQ and other features that rival those three projects: some xx Chain features are much better, and others can be added by integrating the currently unused components of PolkadotSDK.

In terms of PQ features of the chain itself, those chains may be ahead, but they are bogged down in re-developing the same chain features that have been developed elsewhere, with a fraction of Polkadot DAO's resources that xx Network can use for free (and that's not "porting" the way some of these coins do with Ethereum's features, but the relatively simpler "enabling").

Regarding chain features, the three coins are ahead of other chains out there, but their problem can be summarized like so: aside from address readiness (which two seem to have), will other coins out there reach PQ before these coins reach their own escape velocity?

xx Network shouldn't be directly compared with them, but I think it's better in both ways:

  • Chain-wise, some PQ features are less developed, some same or better (Sleeve). But xx Network's non-PQ features are way ahead due to the use of PolkadotSDK and these cost relatively little to develop and advance
  • PQ services-wise, xx Network is focused on messaging and in that area ahead of all three. As for other services (unrelated to messaging mixnet), I think it's better to not focus on many - one use case is hard enough - so it doesn't bother me that cMixx can't do phone calls, or transfer files
